author: Stephanie Farr
title: Sam Psoras, 90, DN photographer
text:
Sam Psoras, 90, DN photographer Updated: February 20, 2017 — 6:27 PM EST Share 

tickled his chin, Frank Sinatra knocked him on his keister, and Joan Crawford once hung on his arm, but for legendary Daily News photographer Samuel (Sam) Psoras, who died on Saturday at the age of 90, photographing cops and firefighters was just as fun as shooting celebrities – and sometimes, even more so. 
‘60s he’d go out to a fire or emergency scene and when it was under control he’d open his trunk and he’d have wine, beer, and soda which he’d give to the emergency responders,” said Psoras’ son, Mark. 
Psoras, who lived in Rhawnhurst, died of cardio-pulmonary arrest at Holy Redeemer Hospital. 
s International News Photos. Psoras was hired by the Daily News in 1950 and worked at the paper until his retirement in 1991. 
“” he said in a video in which he remininced about his career. 
Psoras was there when Martin Luther King Sr. and Martin Luther King Jr. visited the Bright Hope Baptist Church. He was there when Billie Holiday was taken in on drug charges by Philadelphia police in 1956. He was there when the Mercury astronauts, including John Glenn, trained at a centrifuge in the suburbs in the early 1960s. 
He photographed The Beatles, Malcolm X, Grace Kelly, and John F. Kennedy Jr., among others. 
Street Station, Psoras did a solid for a man having an affair with Joan Crawford. The man was waiting for Crawford at the station, but when his wife caught wind of the rendezvous, the man asked Psoras to act like Crawford was there to meet him. 
“” Mark Psoras said. “As my dad walked up Joan put her arms around him, asked his name and said ‘Oh, Sam! Darling!’” 
When Frank Sinatra married Ava Gardner in Philadelphia in 1951, Psoras huddled with other photographers on the porch of a house where the couple was staying. When an angry Sinatra came out, he went after another photographer but that man moved out of the way and Sinatra hit Psoras instead. 
But it was getting to photograph Saint Theresa then Mother Theresa - that was one of the high points of Psoras’ career. When he went in close for the perfect photograph, she tickled him under his chin and called him good-looking in Italian. 
” Psoras said. 
Michael Mercanti, director of photography for the Daily News, Inquirer, and Philly.com, began working with Psoras in the 1980s. 
“’s best friend,” Mercanti said. “Sam was optimistic and enthusiastic, a trusted advisor, a ready source for past Daily News coverage, history, and gossip.” 
Of all the images Psoras created as a photographer, it is an image he created as a father that will stick most with his son. 
“” Mark Psoras said. “I’ll always remember, she took money of our purse and he jumped back and put one hand up saying ‘No, no, no.’ 
“” Mark Psoras said. “He enjoyed people and people enjoyed him.” 
Psoras is survived by his wife of 54 years, Sandra, and his son, Mark. He was preceded in death by his son, Jonathan. February 20, 2017 — 6:25 PM EST Updated: February 20, 2017 — 6:27 PM EST
